Navigation
Name Recipes/Metrics/MeasuringJava/MeasuringClasses
Examples First we import the basic data types for representing Java. The model is called M3, and its definition is split acros a generic language independent module called Rascal:analysis/m3/Core and a Java specific part called Rascal:lang/java/m3/Core. Have a look at the documentation of these modules later. For now we will go through using them in a few examples. 
rascal>import lang::java::m3::Core;
ok
Then we import the API for extracting an M3 model from an Eclipse project. 
rascal>import lang::java::jdt::m3::Core;
ok
Calling the following function generates an enormous value representing everything the Eclipse Java compiler knows about this project: 
rascal>myModel = createM3FromEclipseProject(|project://HelloWorld|);
M3: m3(|project://HelloWorld|)[
  @fieldAccess={
    <|java+method:///HelloWorld/main(java.lang.String%5B%5D)|,|java+field:///HelloWorld/field|>,
    <|java+method:///ByeWorld/main(java.lang.String%5B%5D)|,|java+field:///java/lang/System/err|>,
    <|java+method:///ByeWorld/main(java.lang.String%5B%5D)|,|java+field:///HelloWorld/field|>,
    <|java+method:///HelloWorld/main(java.lang.String%5B%5D)|,|java+field:///java/lang/System/err|>,
    <|java+method:///ByeWorld/main(java.lang.String%5B%5D)|,|java+field:///java/lang/System/out|>,
    <|java+method:///HelloWorld/main(java.lang.String%5B%5D)|,|java+field:///java/lang/System/out|>
  },
  @extends={},

    <|project://HelloWorld/src/ByeWorld.java|(627,5,<38,23>,<38,28>),|java+field:///HelloWorld/field|>,
    <|project://HelloWorld/src/ByeWorld.java|(661,8,<40,23>,<40,31>),|java+method:///java/lang/Object/hashCode()|>,
    <|project://HelloWorld/src/HelloWorld.java|(406,6,<29,8>,<29,14>),|java+class:///java/lang/String|>,
    <|project://HelloWorld/src/ByeWorld.java|(87,1,<5,16>,<5,17>),|java+typeVariable:///T|>,
    <|project://HelloWorld/src/ByeWorld.java|(674,1,<40,36>,<40,37>),|java+variable:///ByeWorld/main(java.lang.String%5B%5D)/a|>,
    <|project://HelloWorld/src/HelloWorld.java|(555,10,<37,2>,<37,12>),|java+class:///HelloWorld|>,
    <|project://HelloWorld/src/HelloWorld.java|(583,10,<37,30>,<37,40>),|java+class:///HelloWorld|>,
    <|project://HelloWorld/src/ByeWorld.java|(564,7,<37,13>,<37,20>),|java+class:///java/lang/Integer|>,
    <|project://HelloWorld/src/ByeWorld.java|(592,7,<37,41>,<37,48>),|java+class:///java/lang/Integer|>,
    <|project://HelloWorld/src/ByeWorld.java|(617,7,<38,13>,<38,20>),|java+method:///java/io/PrintStream/println(java.lang.Object)|>,
    <|project://HelloWorld/src/HelloWorld.java|(627,1,<38,21>,<38,22>),|java+variable:///HelloWorld/main(java.lang.String%5B%5D)/x|>,
    <|project://HelloWorld/src/ByeWorld.java|(468,6,<33,25>,<33,31>),|java+class:///java/lang/String|>,
    <|project://HelloWorld/src/ByeWorld.java|(640,6,<40,2>,<40,8>),|java+class:///java/lang/System|>,
    <|project://HelloWorld/src/HelloWorld.java|(496,3,<34,9>,<34,12>),|java+field:///java/lang/System/out|>,
    <|project://HelloWorld/src/HelloWorld.java|(653,7,<40,13>,<40,20>),|java+method:///java/io/PrintStream/println(int)|>
  },
  @methodOverrides={},
  @types={
    <|java+method:///HelloWorld/x()|,method(
      |java+method:///HelloWorld/x()|,
      [],
      object(),
      [])>,
    <|java+method:///HelloWorld/h()|,method(
      |java+method:///HelloWorld/h()|,
      [],
      char(),
      [])>,
    <|java+variable:///ByeWorld/main(java.lang.String%5B%5D)/x|,class(
      |java+class:///HelloWorld|,
      [class(
          |java+class:///java/lang/Integer|,
          [])])>,
    <|java+method:///ByeWorld/k()|,method(
      |java+method:///ByeWorld/k()|,
      [],
      float(),
      [])>,
    <|java+method:///ByeWorld/j()|,method(
      |java+method:///ByeWorld/j()|,
      [],
      short(),
      [])>,
    <|java+method:///ByeWorld/i()|,method(
      |java+method:///ByeWorld/i()|,
      [],
   ...
Next, let's focus on the containment relation. This defines what parts of the source code are parts of which other parts: 
rascal>myModel@containment
rel[loc from,loc to]: {
  <|java+class:///ByeWorld|,|java+method:///ByeWorld/l()|>,
  <|java+class:///HelloWorld|,|java+method:///HelloWorld/g()|>,
  <|java+class:///ByeWorld|,|java+method:///ByeWorld/i()|>,
  <|java+class:///HelloWorld|,|java+method:///HelloWorld/h()|>,
  <|java+class:///ByeWorld|,|java+method:///ByeWorld/k()|>,
  <|java+class:///ByeWorld|,|java+method:///ByeWorld/one()|>,
  <|java+method:///ByeWorld/main(java.lang.String%5B%5D)|,|java+variable:///ByeWorld/main(java.lang.String%5B%5D)/a|>,
  <|java+class:///HelloWorld|,|java+method:///HelloWorld/main(java.lang.String%5B%5D)|>,
  <|java+class:///ByeWorld|,|java+field:///ByeWorld/field|>,
  <|java+class:///HelloWorld|,|java+method:///HelloWorld/f()|>,
  <|java+class:///HelloWorld|,|java+method:///HelloWorld/x()|>,
  <|java+method:///HelloWorld/main(java.lang.String%5B%5D)|,|java+variable:///HelloWorld/main(java.lang.String%5B%5D)/b|>,
  <|java+compilationUnit:///src/ByeWorld.java|,|java+class:///ByeWorld|>,
  <|java+class:///ByeWorld|,|java+method:///ByeWorld/m()|>,
  <|java+method:///HelloWorld/main(java.lang.String%5B%5D)|,|java+variable:///HelloWorld/main(java.lang.String%5B%5D)/a|>,
  <|java+class:///ByeWorld|,|java+field:///ByeWorld/fields|>,
  <|java+method:///ByeWorld/main(java.lang.String%5B%5D)|,|java+variable:///ByeWorld/main(java.lang.String%5B%5D)/b|>,
  <|java+method:///HelloWorld/main(java.lang.String%5B%5D)|,|java+parameter:///HelloWorld/main(java.lang.String%5B%5D)/args|>,
  <|java+method:///ByeWorld/main(java.lang.String%5B%5D)|,|java+variable:///ByeWorld/main(java.lang.String%5B%5D)/x|>,
  <|java+class:///ByeWorld|,|java+method:///ByeWorld/two()|>,
  <|java+class:///HelloWorld|,|java+method:///HelloWorld/two()|>,
  <|java+class:///ByeWorld|,|java+method:///ByeWorld/f()|>,
  <|java+class:///ByeWorld|,|java+method:///ByeWorld/main(java.lang.String%5B%5D)|>,
  <|java+class:///HelloWorld|,|java+typeVariable:///T|>,
  <|java+class:///ByeWorld|,|java+method:///ByeWorld/x()|>,
  <|java+compilationUnit:///src/HelloWorld.java|,|java+class:///HelloWorld|>,
  <|java+class:///HelloWorld|,|java+method:///HelloWorld/k()|>,
  <|java+class:///HelloWorld|,|java+method:///HelloWorld/m()|>,
  <|java+class:///HelloWorld|,|java+method:///HelloWorld/one()|>,
  <|java+class:///HelloWorld|,|java+method:///HelloWorld/l()|>,
  <|java+class:///HelloWorld|,|java+field:///HelloWorld/field|>,
  <|java+class:///ByeWorld|,|java+method:///ByeWorld/h()|>,
  <|java+class:///ByeWorld|,|java+method:///ByeWorld/g()|>,
  <|java+class:///HelloWorld|,|java+method:///HelloWorld/i()|>,
  <|java+class:///ByeWorld|,|java+typeVariable:///T|>,
  <|java+class:///ByeWorld|,|java+method:///ByeWorld/j()|>,
  <|java+method:///ByeWorld/main(java.lang.String%5B%5D)|,|java+parameter:///ByeWorld/main(java.lang.String%5B%5D)/args|>,
  <|java+class:///HelloWorld|,|java+method:///HelloWorld/j()|>,
  <|java+class:///HelloWorld|,|java+field:///HelloWorld/fields|>,
  <|java+method:///HelloWorld/main(java.lang.String%5B%5D)|,|java+variable:///HelloWorld/main(java.lang.String%5B%5D)/x|>
}
As you can read, classes contain methods, methods contain variables, etc. Classes could also contain other classes (nested classes), and methods can even contain classes (anonymous classes). Let's focus on a specific class, and project what it contains from the relation: 
rascal>myModel@containment[|java+class:///HelloWorld|]
set[loc]: {
  |java+method:///HelloWorld/main(java.lang.String%5B%5D)|,
  |java+field:///HelloWorld/field|,
  |java+field:///HelloWorld/fields|,
  |java+method:///HelloWorld/m()|,
  |java+method:///HelloWorld/l()|,
  |java+method:///HelloWorld/two()|,
  |java+method:///HelloWorld/k()|,
  |java+method:///HelloWorld/j()|,
  |java+method:///HelloWorld/i()|,
  |java+typeVariable:///T|,
  |java+method:///HelloWorld/x()|,
  |java+method:///HelloWorld/h()|,
  |java+method:///HelloWorld/g()|,
  |java+method:///HelloWorld/one()|,
  |java+method:///HelloWorld/f()|
}
Let's filter the methods: 
rascal>helloWorldMethods = [ e | e <- myModel@containment[|java+class:///HelloWorld|], e.scheme == "java+method"];
list[loc]: [
  |java+method:///HelloWorld/main(java.lang.String%5B%5D)|,
  |java+method:///HelloWorld/m()|,
  |java+method:///HelloWorld/l()|,
  |java+method:///HelloWorld/two()|,
  |java+method:///HelloWorld/k()|,
  |java+method:///HelloWorld/j()|,
  |java+method:///HelloWorld/i()|,
  |java+method:///HelloWorld/x()|,
  |java+method:///HelloWorld/h()|,
  |java+method:///HelloWorld/g()|,
  |java+method:///HelloWorld/one()|,
  |java+method:///HelloWorld/f()|
]
And we are ready to compute our first metric. How many methods does this class contain? 
rascal>import List;
ok
rascal>size(helloWorldMethods)
int: 12
No magic applied! It is just a little query on a model that knows everything about the code. Let's generalize and compute the number of methods for all classes in one big expression. First a function to compute the number for a given class: 
rascal>int numberOfMethods(loc cl, M3 model) = size([ m | m <- model@containment[cl], isMethod(m)]);
int (loc, M3): int numberOfMethods(loc, M3);
then we apply this new function to give us a map from classes to integers: 
rascal>map[loc class, int methodCount] numberOfMethodsPerClass = (cl:numberOfMethods(cl, myModel) | <cl,_> <- myModel@containment, isClass(cl));
map[loc class, int methodCount]: (
  |java+class:///HelloWorld|:12,
  |java+class:///ByeWorld|:12
)
how about the number of fields? 
rascal>int numberOfFields(loc cl, M3 model) = size([ m | m <- model@containment[cl], isField(m)]);
int (loc, M3): int numberOfFields(loc, M3);
rascal>map[loc class, int fieldCount] numberOfFieldsPerClass = (cl:numberOfFields(cl, myModel) | <cl,_> <- myModel@containment, isClass(cl));
map[loc class, int fieldCount]: (
  |java+class:///HelloWorld|:2,
  |java+class:///ByeWorld|:2
)
what is the ratio between fields and methods for each class? 
rascal>(cl : (numberOfFieldsPerClass[cl] * 1.0) / (numberOfMethodsPerClass[cl] * 1.0) | cl <- classes(myModel))
map[loc, real]: (
  |java+class:///HelloWorld|:0.1666666667,
  |java+class:///ByeWorld|:0.1666666667
)
